summary.seg: This fifteenth-century medical manuscript appears to have been made in two stages, with a clear distinction between the scripts used on ff. 1r-103v (Part 1) and ff. 104r-149v (Part 2). In the first part of the manuscript, the handwriting seems to be from a slightly earlier period in the fifteenth century compared to that of the second part. It is written almost entirely in Middle English, suggesting that the scribe or compiler participated in what Linda E. Voigts has called a 'groundswell of Englishing' in the fifteenth century: a sudden rush to translate medical texts from Latin into English (Voights 1995: 184).

The first part of this manuscript contains the only known complete copy of a Middle English translation of the Practica brevis, a Latin collection of advice for a wide range of medical ailments and recipes for medicines, compiled by Johannes Platearius II in the first half of the twelfth century at the medical school of Salerno (the only other known Middle English version of the Practica brevis is incomplete, surviving in a sixteenth-century manuscript - now London, British Library, Sloane MS 14 - of only 24 folios). The English version contains sixty-eight chapters, comprising remedies for different types of fever, headaches, aches of the eyes, ears, nose and teeth, mouth ulcers, digestive issues, dropsy, diabetes, unexpected bleeding from various orifices, leprosy, 'wormys in þe wombe', and many more. As Tony Hunt has argued, the English version shows the difficulty of translating medical vocabulary into the vernacular, as many specialised terms are left in the original Latin, then sometimes followed by English clarifications (Hunt 1994: 158). In addition to this translation into English, the Practica brevis was also translated into Anglo-Norman, as discussed by Hunt and Monica Green (Hunt 1994; Green 2009).

The Practica brevis may have been studied and translated at late medieval Oxford, which was a developing centre for the study of medicine; students and scholars often studied medical texts from the established school in Salerno, and the Practica brevis was among them (Getz 1992: 377; Hunt 1994: 149). Faye Getz has noted that, while in Oxford a statute from 1350 prohibiting the practice of medicine by those who had not studied at the university was renewed in 1400, university physicians themselves were concerned that medical information might be used fraudulently but were not against its transmission in general terms. Getz also suggests that the translators of medieval English medical texts may have imagined an audience beyond their own scholarly community (Getz 1992: 396-400; Getz 1990: 2, 9-10). Although there is no concrete evidence linking MS Dd.10.44 to Oxford, it is possible that the manuscript was made with similar motivations to bring the text to a wider and perhaps non-academic audience.

The second part of MS Dd.10.44 contains a variety of recipes for medicines (for example, for making pills and 'electuaries' - medicines made with honey) and herbal texts, listing a range of herbs and their medicinal properties. It also contains several texts concerned with uroscopy - the study of urine for the purpose of medical diagnosis. In the fifteenth-century movement of the 'Englishing' of medical literature, there was a particular interest in making uroscopic medicine more accessible in the vernacular (Jasin 1993). The manuscript not only contains the only complete English version of the Practica brevis, but, as Teresa Tavormina has pointed out, also the only Middle English version of the Letter of Ypocras - an adaptation of a French original with an expanded version of the section on women's urines (2007: 639). The English version of the Practica brevis must have been joined together with this uroscopic material since a very early stage: both parts contain marginal annotations by the same sixteenth-century hand, and William Thorowgood, who recorded the birth of his daughter in 1561 in the first part (f. 102v), also added his ownership inscription in the second part (f. 149r). There seems to have been a tradition of compiling herbal and uroscopy texts together: such combinations also occur in in Cambridge University Library, MSS Dd.6.29 and Ee.1.13. The latter manuscript includes another Middle English version of a text from Salerno: the Circa instans, a compilation of medical recipes that was written by Matthaeus Platearius, a relative of Johannes Platearius. Thus, these manuscripts suggest a strong interest in the knowledge of the Salernitan school among audiences who were reading medical texts in the vernacular.

While the Practica brevis in MS Dd.10.44 is combined with many shorter texts on uroscopy, other manuscripts too suggest that the work was often read within the context of uroscopic medical literature. Uroscopy texts also appear alongside the Latin text of the Practica brevis in other Cambridge manuscripts, including Gonville and Caius MSS 159/209 and 401/623, and Corpus Christi MS 511. But there is also evidence that suggests that the Practica brevis was considered an important source for uroscopic information in its own right: in the incomplete translation in Sloane MS 14, 'vryne' and 'vryna' appear written in the margins 27 times, highlighting the text in the manner of manicules - a medieval annotation technique of drawing pointing hands in the margins to emphasise important sections. The compiler of MS Dd.10.44 therefore is likely to have been aware of the uroscopic context in which the Practica brevis was disseminated, and sought to recreate this context for the English translation as well.

Margaret Connolly has argued that the survival of non-decorated volumes of medical texts suggests that the information they contained was highly valued well beyond the centuries of their production (2016). The numerous annotations in early-modern scripts and appearance of manicules (drawings of pointing fingers, functioning like the modern bookmark) throughout MS Dd.10.44 indicate that this manuscript was used well into the sixteenth century and perhaps beyond. The combination of a Middle English text from Salerno and additional vernacular adaptations of uroscopic texts may have made this manuscript a desirable source of medical learning that contributed to its longevity and survival.

Dr Hope Doherty-Harrison
Teaching Fellow in Medieval Art History
University of Edinburgh

listBibl.bibl: Margaret Connolly, 'Evidence for the Continued Use of Medieval Medical Prescriptions in the Sixteenth Century: A Fifteenth-Century Remedy Book and Its Later Owner', Medical History, 60 (2016), 133–54.

Linda Voigts, 'Multitudes of Middle English Medical Manuscripts, or the Englishing of Science and Medicine', in Manuscript Sources of Medieval Medicine: A Book of Essays, ed. by Margaret Schleissner, Garland Reference Library of the Humanities, v. 1576 (New York: Garland, 1995), pp. 183-197 (p. 184).
Faye Getz, 'Charity, Translation, and the Language of Medical Learning in Medieval England', Bulletin of the History of Medicine, 64 (1990), 1–17 (pp. 2, 9-10, and notes 4, 8).
Vern Bullough, 'Medical Study at Mediaeval Oxford', Speculum, 36 (1961), 600–612.

Ralph Hanna, 'Henry Daniel’s Liber Uricrisiarum', in Popular and Practical Science of Medieval England, ed. by Lister Matheson (East Lansing: Colleagues Press, 1994), pp. 185-219 (p. 188); see also Getz, 'The Faculty of Medicine before 1500', p. 392.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

physDesc.additions: Modern quire numbers in pencil added to the lower right-hand corners of the first rectos of quires.

binding.p: 19th-century (?) brown paper over pasteboard with a brown leather spine.

provenance.p: William Parker (fl. 16th century) Parker, William, fl. 16th century : owned or accessed the book; his name inscribed on f. 149r: 'By me William Parker'.
Francis Slater (fl. 16th century Slater, Francis, fl. 16th century : owned or accessed the book; his name inscribed on f. 149r: 'By me ffrauncis Slater'.
John Young (fl. 16th century) Young, John, fl. 16th century : owned or accessed the book; his name inscribed on f. 149v: 'By me John Yowng'.
John Tyghte (fl. 16th century) Tyghte, John, fl. 16th century : owned or accessed the book; his name inscribed on f. 149v: 'John Tyghte'.

William Thorowgood (fl. 16th century) Thorowgood, William, fl. 16th century : his ownership inscription on f. 149v: 'But I belonge to William Thorowgood only / for to all these he lent me [added:] and nowe was supervisour to Thomas Judwyn his Executour'. Inscribed an entry on the birth of his daughter in 1561 on f. 102v.

John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : uncertain, but suggested by M.R. James. The manuscript has not been identified in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on Margaret Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo), The Index of Middle English Prose (Woodbridge: Brewer, 2009), pp. 26-30 and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.10.44, ff. 1-103

msItem.title: Prologue to the Practica brevis of Johannes Platearius
msItem.author: Johannes Platearius
msItem.incipit: 1r Amicum induit qui iustis amirocum precibus condescendit I plateary for loue of my dyre frendis in þis treteys I am purposid for to shewyn the causes cures ans ignes of sykenes
msItem.explicit: 1r and wyche I was wont most stedefastly to usyn and of wyche I hade most spede for to werk wiþ and ferst I begynne at the feuerys

msItem.title: Table of contents for the Practica brevis of Johannes Platearius
msItem.incipit: 1r Capitulum primum of the feuere the wyche is callyd effimera and where of it is gendrd [sic] and the cure of hym
msItem.explicit: 2v Capitulum .68.m of the wertys and the curee

msItem.title: Practica brevis (English translation)
msItem.author: Johannes Platearius
msItem.incipit: 2v Capitulum primum de febre effimera: Effimera is a fe. that is gendrid of principall dystemperyng of the spiritys and it is causid of trauyl of of [sic] wraythe and of meche vsyng of hotte mette and drynk and som tyme it commythe of coldnes of þe eyr and som tym of sorowe and many other
msItem.explicit: 100v and þat dothe hym away item þe iouce of titunas helpith ȝyf yt be cut ferst abowt Item lat [?] resturporcun dothe that same
msItem.note: The work is divided into sixty-eight chapters.

msItem.title: Two medical recipes for good sight
Dietary advice for the month of May
msItem.rubric: 100v A goode diete for the monyth of may
msItem.incipit: 100v In may aryse erly and vse hote metes and ete no hede nor fete of no beste
msItem.explicit: 100v and ageyne to vse but lytill carnall synne wyth any woman for this is the ordour of maij

msItem.title: Entry on the birth of Anne Thorowgood (1561)
msItem.incipit: 102v An thorowgood my fyrst daughter was born the 6 day of august the year that Pouls Stepil was a f[r]yar anno 1561 beyeng weddensday betwen 9 and 10 of the Clok at nyght in the oner of venvs and in the syn of Cansar god mak her his sarvant amen - Quoth william thorowgood

signatures.p: Arabic numerals in brown or red ink on the right-hand corners of the first rectos of quires; these quire numbers were added at a later stage.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in brown ink in the lower margins of the last versos of quires.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns. 25-31 lines to the page, written above top line.

handNote.p: opied by a single scribe in an Anglicana script.
Medical recipes and dietary information on f. 100v by a scribe in a predominantly Secretary script but also with Anglicana features.

decoNote.p: Large (2- or 5-line) initials in blue or red ink.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.10.44, ff. 104-149

msItem.title: Synonyma (alphabetical list of herbs)
msItem.incipit: 104r Alleluya panis cuculi / Payn de cockyll / Wodsoure / Stubwort
msItem.explicit: 112r zizannia nigella gyth lollium cockill

msItem.title: Note on the use of a herb for escaping chains
msItem.incipit: 112r vt vincula euades accipe herbam fulliuariam [?] quod si vinculat tangas cathene compedis non obstent

msItem.title: Collection of fourteen medical recipes
msItem.note: The collection includes recipes for medical pils and electuaries.

msItem.title: Letter of Ipocras
msItem.rubric: 114r This booke did Ipocrase send vn to Sezar for a gret tresour And therfor kepe it well as your owyn lyfe ffor the made it for help and helth of his body for all maner of yuyles for to exchew
msItem.incipit: 114r ffyrst euery man beste and birde þat hath body hath .4. humoris and namely humoris of mannys body
msItem.explicit: 117v And take of þat powdyr and strawe it on the wounde .3. dayes and than make a tent of lynyn cloth and wete in chyldys pysse or in eysyll and o thus .9. dayes and it shall hele
msItem.note: This is a Middle English version of the Lettre d'Hippocrate (see Dean and Boulton (1999), no. 406), including four sections: a prologue, humoural tract, uroscopy, and a collection of thirty-five recipes that begins with the rubric: Here begynnyth at the hed and so forth to oþer membires. The French version's section on women's urines is not translated but an expanded version of the latter can be found on ff. 144v-145v.

msItem.title: Thesuarus pauperum (English translation)
msItem.author: Petrus Hispanus
msItem.rubric: 117v Here begynnyth the tresour of pore men
msItem.incipit: 117v A gode medicine for the stone and ache of the reynys in the bakke: Take the blode of a fox and anoynte thy yerd þerwyth and it shall breke the stone for why yf thow puttst a stone þerin wyth in .3. daies it shall breke
msItem.explicit: 119v Item a nother: Take a thynne shyuer of bred or tweyne and toste hem well at the fyer and ete theym all hote drye in the morenyng and at evyne but drinke not þerto nor þer aftyr
msItem.note: Recipes and cures for seventeen conditions.

msItem.title: Two medical recipes to cure the plague and incontinence
Liber Edmundi
msItem.textLang: Middle English recipes with one recipe in French and another one in Latin
msItem.rubric: 120r Here beynnyth other medicines at the hede and so forth to other membris of the body etcetera
msItem.incipit: 120r First is for yvyll heryng take eche daye .3. dropis of his owyn pyssyng and o it in his erys in the moreneyng euery day and he shalbe holpyn
msItem.explicit: 123r et calamine pone super morbum et franget et debet sanare vt probatum est a me ipso
msItem.note: A collection of fifty-eight medical recipes in Middle English. One recipe is in French (f. 122v) and one is in Latin (f. 123r).

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 123r Si autem materia fuerit grossa aut subtilis vtatur isto medicamine quod valet ad ad omnia quesita ita que aliquis si vel aliud sciret posset honorifice viuere in hoc mundo
msItem.explicit: 123r et confice cum puluere aloes et camfore
msItem.note: The introduction and first recipe are taken from Bernard de Gordon's Liber de conservatione vitae humanae.

msItem.title: Tretys of diverse herbis
msItem.rubric: 123v Off herbys now I wyll yow tell by and by as I fynde wrytyn in a boke that in borowng I betoke Of a gret Ladyes preste that of a gret name was in hyest
msItem.incipit: 128r At betonye now I wylle begynne that many virtues hath wyth inne
msItem.explicit: 128r It distroyeth the morfew and dispoyling to þe lepyr
msItem.note: This item is not listed in Connolly (2009).

msItem.title: Collection of fifty-three medical recipes
msItem.rubric: 128v Here begynnyth other dyuers medicinis the whiche muste be myxyd wyth Aqua vite as here folowyth
msItem.incipit: 128v fyrst for the feuyr tercian drinke aqua vite wyth the ious of planteyn and sowthystyll
msItem.explicit: 131v ffor a man þat pyssyth ageynst his wylle: take a gotes bladder or a shepys or a netes and brenne it to powdyr þat is to say scoweryd for to pouder it and let him drinke it wyth venegyr or water when he goth to slepe

msItem.title: Medical recipe for bowel disorders
msItem.author: 'Maister Paulyne' [? Paulinus of Leeds]
msItem.rubric: 132r A goode medicine of maister Paulyne for all maner of yvylles. ffor ydropisi discentorie that is flux that whanne of guttes rasyng and blode comyn to gedyr out at atones. ffo þe meneson for chafyng of the boel in a flux. for the bowellys thrylled. for the mydryf for þe lyver. for the cowghe . for colour. or for handys or the lendys. and the iontes. for them þat lykyth nor ther mete. and for all euylles in the hed and in þe body. ffor pissyng. for wodnes. for euyl ende. for whyte of þe yen for felon and for to warisshen woundys. And euery tyme men may it take. And this is þe receyte of þe medicine
msItem.incipit: 132r Take aloes .6. parte of þe receyte .Mirre gumme armoniak pollipodie coste Irios turbentyne gallanum .3. partes
msItem.explicit: 132r And whan thow hast nede make the pelettes hereof of þe gretnes of a pese and gyf the sik man euery day .7. to swalow in fastyng and he shall be holpyn . this medicine men callyth paulines drink
msItem.note: This may be an extract from the 'tretys of Meyster Pawlyn' in San Marino (CA), Huntington Library, MS 1051.

msItem.title: De quatuor infirmitatibus corporum [Four Parts Where the Sicknesses of the Body Begin]
msItem.rubric: 132r Here beth þe .4. partes of man in which euery man comonly is moste and rathest agreuyd wyth euyll þat is to wyt other in the hed or in the brest or in the wombe or in þe bladder and be these tokyns aftyr wryttyn þou shalt knowin which euyll of all these .4. the man is moste agreuyd in
msItem.incipit: 132r ffyrst for þe euyll of þe hed a man may wyt begynnyth when his browes begyn to falle and fawten and myst is in his hed and in his yen
msItem.explicit: 133r And who so vsyth not this medycyne other he shalbe dropyke or chaufyd on the lyuer or the entrayle stoppyd or he shall haue the stone

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.rubric: 133r Diasaturion is callyd of þe rotes of Saturion
msItem.incipit: 133r That is to say the vprysyng of þe ters propirly to theym þat suffyr febylnes of þe reynes for it prouokyth lechory thorow what hap it euyr be for lore wythowtyn eny drechyng it restoryth the ballokys of saturiones all new pastinac notes of ynde
msItem.explicit: 133r-133v and aftyr þat put in thy pouderes aboue said and at þe laste put in mustes wiþ watur of rosez and be it gevyn wyth swete wyne a sponefull attones when þey nede

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.incipit: 133v It is goode for dyuers passions of the hed and for dystemperaunce of the yen and of the erys
msItem.explicit: 133v colloquintida mastik epithium of eche ij scripul aleos the weyght of all þe todyr and hony as moche as suffysyth
msItem.note: The rubric is faded or rubbed and cannot be read with UV light.

msItem.title: De urinis
msItem.rubric: 133v Nota de vrinis: ffor to know þe vryne of syke man and of hole
msItem.incipit: 133v Also here is wrytyn yf the vryne of the syk man be troble and it haue holdyn cloddes fletyng a bouen þat singnifieth þat the deth is prolongyd
msItem.explicit: 134v Vryne of what colour so it be and wanne abouen and sprynkelyng it is signe of lesynge of þe euyll þat is in þe man

msItem.title: The Twenty-Jordans (the circles and contents section)
msItem.incipit: 134v Take hede vn to the Serkyll and yf it be grene it betokenyth gret ache in the ryght syde and yf þe serkyll be whyte it betokenyth ache in þe hynd parte of þe hed
msItem.explicit: 134v Smalle þredes in the water betokenyth drerynes of complexion and a postym in the ryght syde squamus of fysshis stoppyng of flowyres and skabbys and the modyr

msItem.title: Collection of twenty-two medical recipes and one charm
msItem.note: The charm on f. 135r reads: ffor þe crampe: Wryte thes wordys in a strowe . Porro Poca [...] zabata . zay . zezay.

msItem.title: Notes on four medicinal waters and recipes for the stomach and digestion
msItem.rubric: 136r Here shall folow dyuers wateres goode and prophetabyll for many thynges
msItem.incipit: 136r Water of isope is hote and dry and it is goode to distrow the cowghe that commyth of cold
msItem.explicit: 136r for hym þat may not ete take centory weybred and pepyr and seth it in wyne and drinke it kewke warme to bedward

msItem.title: List of 18 medicinal waters and their properties
msItem.incipit: 136v Water of centory is gode for the apetyte for the lyuer for the mylte for wormys and ofr the sawsefleme
msItem.explicit: 137v Water of centory: watyr of centory clensys the syght and helyth and doth away the palsey
msItem.note: On ff. 136v-137r is a synonyma list of waters with Latin names and their English ingredients.

msItem.title: Collection of twenty-eight medical recipes
msItem.note: The last two recipes are in Latin.

msItem.title: A note on the quantities, tastes, and substances of urine
msItem.incipit: 139v It is to be knowyn þat there be .3. quantites in vrine
msItem.explicit: 139v medelyd substaunce betokenth temperaunce
msItem.note: Incomplete fragment of the 'Ten Cold Ten Hot' compendium identified by Tess Tavormina.

msItem.title: The Twenty-Jordan Series [Albus/Lacteus incipit]
msItem.incipit: 140r Color albus vt aqua purissima significat indigestionum This colour is lyke watyr and the colour of glasse in capitulo .4.
msItem.explicit: 143r Make a drinke of þe Juse of selendyn and þe juse of moleyn and tryakell wyth white wyne and vse it erly and late

msItem.title: Note on the four humours
msItem.incipit: 143r Nota þat euery mannys body is made of .4. humores
msItem.explicit: 143r Malencoly reynyth in all þe lymmes frome þe reynys downwarde and þerfore take hede to thes .4. thynges that is the substance þe quantite the colour and the contentis.

msItem.title: A list of the Aegidian contents of urine
msItem.incipit: 143v In vryne bene these contentes .Cerkyll. Ampull. Greynys. Clowdes. Scome. Attyr. ffatnes. Humor. Blode. Gravell. Herys. Scalis. Crinodes. Sperme. Duste. Ashes. Sedimen. or Ipostacis
msItem.explicit: 143v Sedimen id est clowdys in þe grownde of the vryne or brokyn vprward toward the cerkyll is callyd Ipostaces id est grownd and it hath moste signyficacions and namely of the lower partes
msItem.note: This is the '18 Contents' section of the Ten Cold Ten Hot compendium.

msItem.title: Tract on the regions of the 'urinal'
msItem.incipit: 143v Thow shalt vndyrstond þat in þe vrinall þer bene .3. regyons the ffyrst the secunde and þe thyrde. The thyrde begynnyth at the botom of the vrinall and lastyth .2. fyngyrs brede vpward. The secunde region begynnyth ther the thyrde endyth and lastyth vp to the cerkyll and in eueryche of thes regyons aryn dyuers contentes as is before more playnly rehersyd
msItem.note: Full transcription. This is the 'Three Regions' text from the Doom of Urines compendium.

msItem.title: 'The Complexions of Urine' and 'Where the Complexions are Generated'
msItem.rubric: 144r To know þe .4. complexions of man by the vrine at euery tyme
msItem.incipit: 144r Beholde yf the vryne be thyke and rede thanne hyt betokenyth blode
msItem.explicit: 144r Malencoly is engendyrd in the lyuyr and his propyr dwellyng is in þe splene and malencoly and fflewme coueryth the botome of the vryne
msItem.note: These tracts are segments of the Doom of Urines compendium.

msItem.title: Extract from The Dome of Uryne Compendium
msItem.incipit: 144r Also þer is a content þat is callyd Ipostaces in latyn and þat stondyth in þe botome brode beneth and sharpe vpward above
msItem.explicit: 144v And yf it be blake it betokenyth destruccion of kynde and deth

msItem.title: The Content of Woman's Urines
msItem.incipit: 144v Womans vryne þat is raye and clere and schynyth as it were syluyr and the woman castytth at morne and aftyr calmys and brakyth and wexyth blo vndyr þe yen is sygne þat she is wyth chylde
msItem.explicit: 145v and qwyche humouris being of cold takyng
msItem.note: A list of the 20 contents of women's urine that appears to be an expanded version of the section on women's urine in the French Lettre d'Hippocrate.

msItem.title: List of contents of urine
msItem.rubric: 145v Here folowyth oþer contentes of vryne
msItem.incipit: 145v Vryne myche in quantite grene and derke frome þe botome to the myddys it betoknyth þe spirituall vesselles is stoppyd and the bowelles
msItem.explicit: 148r Vrine rede that hath knottys of blode is signe of myche yvyll beyng in the stomake

signatures.p: Arabic numerals in brown ink on the lower right-hand corners of the first rectos of quires ('12'-'16'); these quire numbers were added at a later stage.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns. 31-32 lines to the page, written above top line.

handNote.p: Copied by a single scribe in a predominantly Secretary script but also with Anglicana features.
Medical recipes and dietary information by a scribe in a predominantly Secretary script but also with Anglicana features.

decoNote.p: Large (2-line) initials in red or blue ink.
Paraphs in blue or red ink.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
